text:
Ever wondered what the cast of The Avengers
looked like before they became Earth's mightiest

superheroes? Here's a special S.H.I.E.L.D.
report about their origins, back when they

were fighting acne, '80s fashion trends, and
bad haircuts.
Iron Man

Back in the day, Robert Downey Jr. moved with
his father to California, where he enrolled

in Santa Monica High School. But he dropped
out before graduation, moving to New York

to pursue acting. Despite battles with addiction
and the law, he's ultimately become one of

the most successful working actors in the
biz.
Captain America

Once, Chris Evans was just a dorky middle
school kid like everybody else. Proof of this

came in a 2011 episode of Late Night with
Jimmy Fallon, when Fallon surprised Evans

with a bunch of his old yearbook photos. Of
course, he grew out of his braces and bowl

cut to become Captain America. Good thing,
too. You can't punch Nazis with hair like
that.
Black Widow

Scarlett Johansson's been in the acting game
since childhood. Before becoming an agent

of S.H.I.E.L.D., she made her feature debut
in the comedy North and followed with roles

in Home Alone 3 and The Horse Whisperer. Since
then, ScarJo has enjoyed critical acclaim

and box office success thanks to films like
Lost in Translation. But the role we want

her to take on the most? The lead in a Black
Widow movie. C'mon, Marvel!
Hulk

Young Mark Ruffalo competed in wrestling tournaments
throughout high school. But he gave it up

to pursue acting his senior year. After starring
in critically acclaimed movies for years,

Ruffalo entered the Marvel universe in 2010
when he was cast to play the Hulk—the third

actor to take the role in seven years. But
he's the one that stuck: fans have been hoping
for a stand-alone Hulk movie ever since.
Hawkeye

Before Jeremy Renner dove into acting, the
California native was actually considering

a career in computer science, before he realized
he wouldn't fit in well with that crowd. Thank

goodness he lost the mullet, got off the computer,
and picked up a bow. By the late-2000s, Renner

became a household name thanks to back-to-back
Oscar nominations for The Hurt Locker and

The Town. He landed the role of Hawkeye in
2011, giving the beloved character his big
screen debut in the first Thor movie.
Nick Fury

Hollywood legend Samuel L. Jackson grew up
in Chattanooga, Tennessee, and went on to

study at Morehouse College in Atlanta. Jackson
told Parade magazine he fell in with the "radical

faction" of the Civil Rights movement while
at Morehouse...until the FBI came to his mother's

house and allegedly made threats. He traded
politics for acting when he returned to Morehouse

in 1971. These days, Jackson's career speaks
for itself. He plays superspy Nick Fury in

Marvel's movieverse, and has huge roles in
films like The Hateful Eight and Kingsman:
The Secret Service.
Scarlet Witch

As a youngster, Elizabeth Olsen dove into
the acting business by appearing in a few

projects starring her famous sisters, the
Olsen twins. After "retiring" from acting

at age 10, she picked it back up when she
studied the craft at NYU. In 2011, she got

her big break in the drama Martha Marcy May
Marlene. After a brief cameo in Captain America:

The Winter Soldier, Olsen made her own official
Marvel debut as the Scarlet Witch in Avengers:
Age of Ultron.
Thor

Born in Melbourne, Australia, actor Chris
Hemsworth spent his youth moving between the

city and the Outback. But it wasn't long before
he dove into acting. After scoring early roles

on the Australian family series Guinevere
Jones and the U.K. soap Neighbours, Hemsworth

landed a long-running gig on the Australian
serial Home and Away. Nearly 200 episodes

later, he left for Hollywood, where he found
fast success: a brief appearance in 2009's

Star Trek reboot led to a quick series of
roles culminating in his coronation as the

mighty Asgardian. Since soaring to superstardom
as Thor, Hemsworth has continued to book a

variety of jobs, from dramas like Rush to
comedies like Vacation and the Ghostbusters
reboot.
Vision

Paul Bettany took the long road to Hollywood,
spending a period subsisting as a street performer

after a family tragedy led to him leaving
home in his teens. At 19, he enrolled at the

Drama Centre in London, which led to roles
in a series of stage productions—and his

screen debut in a 1994 episode of the British
crime drama Wycliffe. Bettany's gifts quickly

caught the eye of directors, and after earning
acclaim for his work in the 2000 British film

Gangster No. 1, he picked up roles in A Knight's
Tale, A Beautiful Mind, and Master and Commander:

The Far Side of the World. He made his Marvel
debut as the voice of Tony Stark's AI assistant,

JARVIS, in Iron Man before being brought fully
online as the Vision in Avengers: Age of Ultron.
Ant-Man

Long before he became Ant-Man, Paul Rudd was
just another long-haired frat boy at the University

of Kansas. While in college, Rudd actually
became friends with Mad Men star Jon Hamm

in Kansas City, where they both grew up. Since
then, Rudd's been a constant presence on-screen

over the years, from Clueless to Anchorman,
and everything in between. But who could've

predicted his biggest role yet would actually
be...so small?

Thanks for watching! Subscribe to our YouTube
channel to watch more videos like the one

you just saw. And leave us a comment to let
us know which Avenger is your favorite...
